importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the termination of the JCPOA, signaling a major shift in Iran's nuclear program and international relations.
The original adoption of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) by the UN Security Council, setting the 10-year timeline for the deal's expiration.
The United States unilaterally withdrew from the JCPOA under President Donald Trump, leading to the reimposition of sanctions and a shift in Iran's nuclear activities.
The UK, Germany, and France triggered the 'snapback' mechanism, formally re-imposing UN sanctions and effectively ending the agreement's operational life.
A 12-day war between the US and Iran targeted nuclear sites, causing significant civilian casualties and damage, leading to Iran's suspension of cooperation with the IAEA.
Iran’s President Masoud Pezeshkian signed a law suspending cooperation with the IAEA, marking a significant deterioration in transparency and international verification.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period from the adoption of UN Security Council Resolution 2231 to the termination of the JCPOA defines the lifespan of the nuclear agreement and its geopolitical impact.
This period reflects the years of US withdrawal, sanctions, and Iran’s increasing nuclear program, culminating in the snapback and deal termination.

keyTakeAways: The JCPOA, a landmark nuclear deal, officially expired on 2025-10-18 after 10 years, with Iran asserting it is no longer bound by its restrictions.
The US left the deal in 2018, leading to renewed nuclear activities in Iran and a long-standing diplomatic stalemate.
The snapback mechanism triggered by the UK, Germany, and France in August 2024 effectively ended the deal's operational viability, despite Iran's formal declaration of termination.
Iran has suspended cooperation with the IAEA following the 2024 US-Israeli military attacks, undermining verification mechanisms and international confidence.
Western powers and Israel accuse Iran of pursuing nuclear weapons, but the IAEA and US intelligence have found no evidence of weapons development as of 2025.
Iran remains open to diplomacy, but only under conditions of guarantees against military action, reflecting deep mistrust in US intentions.
The US and Israel's 2024 military actions in Iran have severely damaged diplomatic prospects and created a hostile environment for renewed negotiations.
Current diplomatic efforts to revive the JCPOA are stalled, with Iran rejecting engagement with the Europeans due to their role in triggering the snapback.

namedEntities.name: Iran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that previously agreed to nuclear restrictions under the JCPOA, now asserting it is no longer bound by those restrictions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Iran is the central actor in the nuclear dispute, and its declaration of termination of the JCPOA marks a pivotal shift in its nuclear policy and international relations.

namedEntities.name: Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 2015 nuclear agreement between Iran and world powers to limit Iran’s nuclear programme in exchange for sanctions relief.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The JCPOA is the focal point of the article, as its expiration and termination have major implications for global nuclear non-proliferation and international diplomacy.

namedEntities.name: United States (US)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A world power that withdrew from the JCPOA in 2018 and reinstated sanctions, currently seeking a new deal with Iran.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is a key player in the nuclear negotiations and its unilateral withdrawal significantly altered the course of the agreement and Iran's nuclear development.

namedEntities.name: United Kingdom (UK)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A world power that participated in the JCPOA and triggered the snapback mechanism in 2024, re-imposing sanctions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK’s role in triggering the snapback mechanism directly contributed to the formal end of the JCPOA's effectiveness and legitimacy.

namedEntities.name: Germany
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A world power that participated in the JCPOA and triggered the snapback mechanism in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Germany’s involvement in the snapback mechanism underscored the collective failure of European powers to revive the deal and re-established sanctions.

namedEntities.name: France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A world power that participated in the JCPOA and triggered the snapback mechanism in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: France’s participation in the snapback mechanism marked a decisive step in ending the JCPOA, signaling a collapse of European diplomatic engagement.

namedEntities.name: Russia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A world power that participated in the JCPOA, though not directly involved in the snapback or current negotiations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Russia’s inclusion in the original deal highlights its role in the international nuclear diplomacy framework, though it is not currently active in current talks.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China’s participation in the original agreement reflects the global consensus on nuclear non-proliferation, even as it is not involved in current diplomatic efforts.

namedEntities.name: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A UN agency responsible for monitoring nuclear activities and verifying compliance with non-proliferation agreements.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IAEA’s suspension of inspections due to the 2024 attacks and lack of condemnation has undermined transparency and trust in Iran’s nuclear program.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of Iran project at International Crisis Group who evaluated the state of the deal.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vaez’s assessment that the deal is 'lifeless' and the snapback has 'buried' it adds credibility to the article’s claim of deal collapse.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iran has declared that the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) — a landmark nuclear deal with world powers — has officially terminated after exactly 10 years. Despite this announcement, the deal is effectively dead due to the UK, Germany, and France triggering the 'snapback' mechanism in August 2024, which re-imposed UN sanctions and ended the agreement's operational life. Iran has since suspended cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) following military strikes in June 2024, which killed civilians and damaged nuclear sites. The US, which withdrew from the deal in 2018 under President Donald Trump, remains engaged in diplomatic talks, but Iran insists on guarantees against military action. Experts say the deal is now 'lifeless' and the current diplomatic deadlock reflects deep mistrust between Iran and Western powers, with no prospects for immediate revival.
title: Iran says restrictions on nuclear programme ‘terminated’ as deal expires
